I am wanting to buy a new pistol, and was just wondering what comes to mind for people. I have a few in mind, but I want to know if I am overlooking any good options. 
 
 I am looking for something:
 Compact
 9mm or .40 S&W
 lightweight
 good capacity (at least 10 +1)
 reliable (no Bryco's!!!)
 reasonably priced (less than $600)
 
 Any ideas?

I am a big fan of Para Ord pistols. They are primarily .45, but they have some in other calibers. For a compact, check out the Warthog or the Nighthawg at paraord.com. 
 Dono

there are lots of pistols that will fit that bill. 
 CZ's http://www.cz-usa.com/products_handguns.php?m=1
 H&K's http://www.hecklerkoch-usa.com/index.jsp?loc=101&SITEID=A&PartNumber=704531 they run right along the top of your price limit.
 taurus's http://www.taurususa.com/products/products-pistols.cfm
 the list goes on and on. 
 
 you can find some good deales at cdnn investments http://www.cdnninvestments.com/dowournewcat.html , but you have to down load the catalog.

I have a Glock 27 in .40, and have found it to be a very reliable CCW. Expect to pay $500-550 for it. I have no complaints. It never jams. It's 9+1 in .40 and 10+1 in 9mm. Not as accurate as my Kimber .45 CDPII, but much less expensive and the Glock fits easily in the front pocket of a pair of jeans. You can also pick it up in .357 Sig. A lot of Va. state troopers carry the 27 in .357 as an off-duty weapon because that's the state police duty weapon cartridge.
 
 For whatever weapon you choose I would take .40 over the 9 because it's just a better cartridge. My Sheriff's department gave up on the 9mm last year and switched to .40 because they have seen the 9 is just not enough gun for them.
 
 Oh, for those who are curious and want to know why I think I should own two handguns---it's because I can (and it keeps the wife from poaching my Kimber when she's on the road).

If you're after concealment my favorite and regular carry is the Kel-Tec .380.
 Fits in the watch pocket of a pair of Levis, feeds six hollow points flawlessly and weighs almost nothing. Several of our deputy sheriffs carry them as summer off-duty pieces, which is how I discovered the convenience. 
 
 If I'm in a vehicle, there's always a Sig or Glock within easy reach. If I'm in the truck or on the quad, something more substantial being available.
 
 And not just for human critters, I recently saw two full-grown cougars run across the road a few hundred yards from my house. First time I've ever seen more than one at a time of what are normally very territorial animals. Between cougars and humans, I consider the human the more dangerous animal. Especially since crystal meth has become the street drug of choice in my locale.
I would recommend a Magnum P.I. emoticon_xangel

If you're after concealment my favorite and regular carry is the Kel-Tec .380.
 Fits in the watch pocket of a pair of Levis, feeds six hollow points flawlessly and weighs almost nothing. Several of our deputy sheriffs carry them as summer off-duty pieces, which is how I discovered the convenience.

 That is a nice little pistol with lots of smack for only 11 onces. Also, I like DA automatics.

If you want a 9, the P228 is absolutly unbeatable. It is one of the cheaper guns I own, but I have put thousands of rounds through it and it has NEVER had a feed problem. Not even once. It is the only gun I have ever owned that I can say that about. Even my glocks have occasionally just decided not to eat a round. The 228 is a little pricier new than what you are lookig ot spend, but I would have absolutly no reservations about buying one on the second hand market. 
 
 The Kimber Ten II in .45 is a nice weapon and has the mag capacity and the price you are looking for, but it just does not feel right in my hand. Your hand may be different.
 
 In .40, the glock 22 is an OK weapon, with a low price tag (around $600). The 4006 from smith is a nice looking weapon, but I found the slide to be stiff, and the trigger pull was TERRIBLE. Stay away form the Walther p99. It is constnatly decocking the striker rather than firing, and I have only ever managed to get a few clips to fire wihtout the slide locking back prematurely. I can't even sell the POS. 
 
 My choice in the .40 has to be either the HK USP, a fine pistol if ever there was one, OR, the P229 from Sig. When I got my P229, the first 20 or 30 rounds the slide failed to lock back occasionally when the mag was empty. After that, it has functioned flawlessly for the thousands of rounds I have put through it. The initial slide lock problem is the only reason I do not rate it quite as high for reliability as the P228, which is always perfect right out of the box. It is almost like the lcokign mechanism was a little stiff from the factory and had to loosen up a bit.
 
 Really, the 228 or 229 would be my choice. Glock makes a fine weapon, but I think that Sig beats them by a hair. BUT, when youa re talking somethign that you may have to bet your life on, whether a hair or a mile does not matter, what matters is that they are beat.
 
 
 In the end, the best gun is the one you can hit with, and the only way you are going to know what you can hit with is by goign out and shooting a bunch of different models. Not all guns are the same. For example, I can hit GREAT with the P228 or P229. I can do 2" groups with them with the sights off the gun. A P226, though, has a little different grip angle and I can't hit with it worth a damn. My wife hits really well with a colt, full sized or commander size, but you hand her a Glock and she could not hit a barn if she was standing in it. I do some competition shooting with a .45. After shooting a really good score one day, a buddy tossed me a .45 that was kind of funny feeling. I shot twice and missed the target completely on both shots. It was a Llama and the grip angle is a little different and the barrel to top of slide is a little taller than most .45s. On the other hand, the modified colt that I shoot in competition has a vastly differnt grip angle than my STI, but I hit with both just fine. 
 
 There seems to just be a narrow range for most folks that, if they are unlucky enough to be holding a pistol that falls in that range, their hand eye coordination goes to hell or they cannot hold their arm quite steady with their wrist at certain angles. I don't know exactly why it is, but I DO know that is why elite military units (seals, delta force, etc..) are allowed to pick their own sidearms. In fact, in some units, if they don't have anything that seems to work for you, they will order you something special. Thats is because those guys are expected to be able to double tap a head in a very short time, every time. You cannot do that if you and your weapon are incompatible.

I almost forgot! If you want to go bargain hunting, I have always liked the Ruger P series (P85, etc..) I can usually find them around here used for $250-$300 and they are fine weapons. If you keep it clean, they are every bit as good as the Sig (I like the sig becuase it does not matter if it is clean or not). Nice, good shooting guns!
 
 Just think, if you go that route, you would either have $300-$350 left in your budget to buy ammo, OR you could buy TWO and get some ammo burnign 2 handed shooting going. I don't think they came in a left hadned model (left eject), or if they did, I haev never seen one :)

Oh, for those who are curious and want to know why I think I should own two handguns---it's because I can (and it keeps the wife from poaching my Kimber when she's on the road).

 IMHO you should own 2 of your main carry weapon. if you ever need to use the weapon, the cops are likly to take it with them. that is not the time to be trying to remember how your other ones work for carry.
 
 
For whatever weapon you choose I would take .40 over the 9 because it's just a better cartridge. 

 it is all about shot placement, not cal. the 9mm is cheaper, witch will allow for more range time. 
 cops are not alwase knowen for there shooting ability.

it is all about shot placement, not cal. the 9mm is cheaper, witch will allow for more range time. 
 cops are not alwase knowen for there shooting ability.

 
 This is true. In a perfect world. In the real world, sometimes you have to take the shot you can take. If all shots were double taps to the head, we could all carry .22s and be fine. If the only shot you can get is a center of mass shot or (ugh) a soft tissue shot, the .40 could give you an advantage.
 
 Then again, considering the excess magazine capacity in most 9mm pistols, there is no reason to ever fire a single shot at an adversary. With .40 or .45, you often are wise to try to conserve ammo where you can, which may cause you to hesitate to pop off that second or third round. I will take 2 9mm rounds over 1 .40 rd any day. 
 
 you make a good point about ammos as well. With all the high quality surplus 9mm on the market at dirt cheap prices, you can afford to shoot a LOT. It is so cheap that you loose money reloading it.

it is all about shot placement, not cal. the 9mm is cheaper, witch will allow for more range time. 
 cops are not alwase knowen for there shooting ability.

 
 Agreed on the placement and 9mm cost, but our sheriff's department has strict pistol qualifying standards. They've dropped candidates who were weak on qualifying at the range.
 
 The problem with LE and civilians being poor shots in an exchange of gunfire is the adrenaline factor overcoming even years of simulated training. There are countless instances of LE emptying clips of 15+ rounds at close range adversaries, missing every shot.
 
 There are also countless stories of highly trained soldiers in battle endlessly pulling the trigger on empty clips, aiming and pulling the trigger with no clip in the weapon, exhausting clip after clip without aiming and every other goof a crazed mind can conjure up in high stress circumstance. I can't remember the numbers, but battle planing for regular field soldiers includes a tremendous amount of ammunition to kill ratio due to the stress factor erasing training skills.

There are also countless stories of highly trained soldiers in battle endlessly pulling the trigger on empty clips, aiming and pulling the trigger with no clip in the weapon, exhausting clip after clip without aiming and every other goof a crazed mind can conjure up in high stress circumstance. I can't remember the numbers, but battle planing for regular field soldiers includes a tremendous amount of ammunition to kill ratio due to the stress factor erasing training skills.

 I read somewhere that they have modified the M-16 from full auto to 3-round bursts because of this.
 Speaking of guns, I see where the Israelis are developing what appears to be a great assault rifle. It appears to be very short yet has a 300M effective range because the receiver is almost at the shoulder giving the short weapon more barrel length.
 Dono

This is true. In a perfect world. In the real world, sometimes you have to take the shot you can take. If all shots were double taps to the head, we could all carry .22s and be fine. If the only shot you can get is a center of mass shot or (ugh) a soft tissue shot, the .40 could give you an advantage.

 every weapon is a compromise, if we knew when we would need a gun, we would carry a rifle that day. it all comes down to what can you hit the target with best, some people are sentive to recoil (i havent found any thing other than a .22 handgun the wife likes shooting), others like shooting the heavy hitters.
 
 
The problem with LE and civilians being poor shots in an exchange of gunfire is the adrenaline factor overcoming even years of simulated training. There are countless instances of LE emptying clips of 15+ rounds at close range adversaries, missing every shot.
 

 stress is the main reason for bad shooting in a real situation, the fine moter skills are the first to go. when you compound that with fireing your weapon once a year to qualifie, the skills are not there. 
 
 
I read somewhere that they have modified the M-16 from full auto to 3-round bursts because of this.

 that would be the M16A2. they changed it to 3-round burst due to the recoil of fireing full automatic will push your muzzle up above your target, so you are just wasting ammo.

Thanks for all of the suggestions! I had been looking at the Glock 19 and 22, Ruger P, Taurus Millenium Pro, and a few others. Never been exposed to Para Ord before, they do look nice. 
 
 Basically this will be my CCW. I am also getting involved with a Tactical EMS Team, and I am able to carry concealed during entry as a back-up only. I want something relatively small and easy to carry, but with enough knock-down power to get the job done quickly. I have a Magnum Research / IMI Baby Eagle .40, but this is just to bulky and heavy of a weapon to be a good CCW. I also have a nice Taurus Revolver, but again, not too easily concealed, and I will certainly not rely on a 6 shot. Again, thanks for all the info. 
 
 BTW: If anyone is interested, I found a good website.
 
 http://www.shootguns.info/maker.htm

Again all, thanks for the info. I just picked up my new Glock 27 in .40 yesterday, and I already love it. Feels nice in my hand, good balance, and I love the weight (or lack of weight). Came with 2 9 round mags, but I also got the grip extending mags that add 2. I already shot it in both configs, and I really prefer the grip extension, but it still fires and seats in my hand very well with the factory mags. 
 
 Also, came with a custom "carbon fiber" finish on the receiver by Dynamic Finishes. Looks absolutely incredible. Check them out, they can do some really cool custom work. 
 
 http://dynamicfinishes.com/

I would have to say a Sig P229 SAS. It comes in 9mm or .40 s&w. Or if you're looking for something cheaper, a Glock 22, a Glock 19, a Glock 17, or a Glock 16 would be sufficiant. But if you want a really nice gun, I'd go with the sig even though its a bit more pricey.
 
 Or, a CZ 75 would be a good substitue for a glock considering their price.

And if you're looking for a carry gun, i'd suggest a Taurus Model 905ICH1, 9mm Revolver, with a Blue Steel concealed hammer.
 
 My second choice would be a a Ruger SP101 in .357 magnum for a carry gun, but thats a .357 mag, and you want a 9mm or .40 s&w.

Depends on what you are going to use it for. I once owned a Beretta 92FS. It was LOUD, and I couldn't hit the side of a barn. I own a Ruger bull barrel 22 and I love it. I'm not a particularly good shot but I can usually put most of the shots into the bullseye. And they can easily be fitted with a laser sight. The way I see it, three shots to the head is going to stop anyone providing they all land where they need to be. A dozen 9 mms that land in the next county aren't going to do much except wake the neighbors. If you want real stopping power, get a 12 gauge shotgun. I have a Mossberg and I would doubt anyone would survive it. I like the 22's simply because they don't have a loud report and they are very accurate. Don't let anyone tell you they are a playgun. They aren't. And the ammo is dirt cheap. And my 22 Marlin rifle is cheap and accurate. But IF you really, really, really want to stop an elephant get a .357 Magnum. There ain't nobody walking away from one of those cannons and you can use 38s for practice. But for an easily consealable handgun, I would recommend a good short barreled revolver. An automatic is always a greater danger for jamming than a revolver. And all you have to do with the revolver is just pull the trigger providing the safety is off. My $0.02 from an occasional shooter.
 
 If you MUST have a 9 mm automatic I would go with the Sig or Glock.

And if you're looking for a carry gun, i'd suggest a Taurus Model 905ICH1, 9mm Revolver, with a Blue Steel concealed hammer.
 
 My second choice would be a a Ruger SP101 in .357 magnum for a carry gun, but thats a .357 mag, and you want a 9mm or .40 s&w.

 
 I still recommend the Kel-Tec P3 for concealed carry as mentioned in an earlier post in this thread. The convenience and efficiency will make anyone who tries it a believer.

If you want real stopping power, get a 12 gauge shotgun. I have a Mossberg and I would doubt anyone would survive it.

 
But IF you really, really, really want to stop an elephant get a .357 Magnum. There ain't nobody walking away from one of those cannons and you can use 38s for practice.

 shot placement counts more that cal.

 but when a revolver gets jammed (and yes, they do) you are likly to need a smith.

 the name on the side dosnt matter much, get what feels good in you hand, and is of a size you will carry.

 That's why I recommended the Rugar 22. I guarantee three shots to the head will stop anyone.

I guarantee three shots to the head will stop anyone.
 

 there are cases of point blank shooting that have failed to stop people. there are no guaranteed man stoppers out there.

there are cases of point blank shooting that have failed to stop people. there are no guaranteed man stoppers out there.

 
 True. I actually saw a guy take about 10-12 rounds in the chest one night before he finally fell (and no, he was not wearing a vest). It's amazing what a little PCP, a lot of alcohol, and a really bad attitude will do to a person. He was still charging towards PD after taking the first 5 or 6 rounds. Of course, when he hit the ground he was pretty much dead right there. 
 
 Then again, I have also seen people who have taken 2 or 3 rounds to the chest still walk to my ambulance.
 
 All in all though, I trust my life to a .40 with 10 rounds of 155gr Hydra-Shok. If I can't hit and disable someone with 10 rounds, I should not be carrying the gun in the first place.

I still recommend the Kel-Tec P3 for concealed carry as mentioned in an earlier post in this thread. The convenience and efficiency will make anyone who tries it a believer.

 
 Even thought that is a great carry gun, i prefer revolvers. They are much more simple to work and generally are smoother than autopistols. But, thats just me. You probably know better because i've never carried, only fired.

These are my reccomendation pictures:
 
 For the taurus 905

 For the sig p239 SAS
 
 And i think most already know what the glocks look like. As i said, i would use the Taurus for carry and the Sig for home defense.
 
 Oh yea, and heres the ruger

Even thought that is a great carry gun, i prefer revolvers. They are much more simple to work and generally are smoother than autopistols. But, thats just me. You probably know better because i've never carried, only fired.

 
 There's no operating difference between double action revolvers and double action auto loaders; pull the trigger and one round fires. 
 
 Try carrying concealed for a long period of time in warm climates and you'll discover how cumbersome a wheelgun can be. I've put many rounds through 
 double action auto loaders without failures, but I stick to FMJ ammunition. Many auto loaders will not handle the 'home defense' rounds due to the bullet hanging up on the feed ramp.

There's no operating difference between double action revolvers and double action auto loaders; pull the trigger and one round fires.

 
 I read a G&A article on this matter. It seemed pretty interesting, and i've always been a fan of the revolver.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Try carrying concealed for a long period of time in warm climates and you'll discover how cumbersome a wheelgun can be. I've put many rounds through 
 double action auto loaders without failures, but I stick to FMJ ammunition. Many auto loaders will not handle the 'home defense' rounds due to the bullet hanging up on the feed ramp.

 
 I just like the simplicity of the revolver. It is much easier to work and a lot faster to load. If you don't know how to work a gun very well, or just want a simple gun, I would suggest a revolver.
It does not matter to me what sort of gun you get, so long as it is legal and you use it safely. (Though I would rather you not get a machine gun lol)
